Post: During an interview, I allow a candidate to use the internet 🌎To get help on code syntax, etc. I pay attention to what exactly they search for. It helps me understand how they navigate through an abundance of information to find the necessary ingredients for accomplishing a given task. After all, that's exactly what they will be doing after they are hired!In short: Search Skill > Memorization Skill#interview

The value of 1 Crore, after: - 10 years from now= 50Lakhs.- 15 years from now= 36Lakhs.- 20 years from now= 25Lakhs.(Assume: 7% inflation) Mutual Funds show you the opposite picture: invest 10K/month for 20 years. And, you will get 1Cr.But, do understand the true value of that 1Cr, 20 years from now.Therefore, the goal should not necessarily be to make 1Cr.The goal should be to grow your money faster than inflation.*****Equity Investing is ONE of the many options. If you are exploring this route, you can check my Free List here (https://lnkd.in/envmhA7e)

Mit viel Freude haben wir den Lernenden von Hewlett Packard Enterprise, HP Inc. und DXC einen Einblick in die Grundlagen des Marketings vermittelt. Im Workshop haben wir den Marketing-Mix erläutert und aufgezeigt, warum eine Zielgruppenanalyse wichtig ist. Wir haben auch erklärt, dass man heute nicht nur von den 4, sondern von den 7 P's spricht und wie sich Offline- von Online-Medien unterscheiden. Durch praktische Übungen in der Gruppe konnten die Teilnehmer:innen das Gelernte direkt anwenden und vertiefen. Natürlich kam auch der Spass nicht zu kurz. Am Ende des Workshops haben wir ein Kahoot-Quiz veranstaltet, bei dem Wissen und Schnelligkeit gefragt waren, um einen der drei kleinen Preise zu gewinnen.Es hat uns als #Praxisbildnern sehr viel Freude bereitet, unser Wissen und unsere Erfahrungen weiterzugeben, um den Lernenden einerseits dabei zu helfen, die Prüfung erfolgreich zu meistern und andererseits ihr Interesse an einer #Karriere im Marketing-Bereich zu wecken.#wearehpe #marketing #learning #knowhowtransfer #fun #readyforthefuture Anita Bräker Oliver Scheidegger Loretta Ftaq Hussein Rahhal Florina Ajdari Tharmila Thayaparan Sabrina Kistler Adriana Miani Florian Käfer Madeleine Selak Roger Fontana Manuel Both Corinne Rennie

I love this challenge coin my leaders Robert (Steve) Stoker and Anibal "J.R." Nieves at work gave us!Traditionally, challenge coins are given to service members and law enforcement personnel for achievement, recognition and morale. So in that same spirt we have been given this coin. You can see the Microsoft logo and the mission statement on the front. Then on the back the team I am apart of and the AD Ninja logo. This logo and idea came around internally around 6 years ago by highly esteemed colleague Justin Turner. The idea is that we are AD Ninjas fighting for our customers and colleagues on advisory, break/fix and disaster recovery of AD environments and to encourage continued AD learning. I actually created the artwork for the coin as one of my leaders reached out asking if I would like to assist in bringing the challenge coin idea to life. You may notice a misspelling which took place during the proofing process (I assure you all, in my artwork there were no misspellings) of the coin development which just makes this coin even more unique if you ask me. We all laugh about it now.It's great to work in an environment where you are appreciated! #Microsoft #MicrosoftEmployee #MicrosoftLife #ChallengeCoin #MoraleGift #Coin #Morale

300...not days or months but years!By now you all should have read that true gender equality is “300 years away”. https://lnkd.in/e4hVVtau#InternationalWomensDay is this week and we at Meta will be celebrating all the brilliant women in our global workforce! 🎉♀️But not only this week or months, a diverse and inclusive workspace is a fundamental part of Meta’s success and philosophy. That’s why we are steadily working on creating the Metaverse with #Diversity, #Equity and #Inclusion in mind - because only  when everyone has an equal voice can we develop more inclusive products for people around the world. 🌍Research by McKinsey also proves women to be a driving force in implementing the #metaverse. It showed that female executives are 20% more likely to set up multiple metaverse initiatives than their male counterparts and that women overall are more likely to utilize hybrid use cases of the metaverse, such as gaming, live events, and shopping via AR/VR technologies. And as they illustrate so well, now it is time to increase the number of women in #leadership roles - across the metaverse and the entire industry. At Meta we doubled the number of women in our global workforce compared to 2019 and increased female leadership positions to a total of 37,1% - and we won’t stop there! 🚀Read more about our efforts to build an inclusive and equal metaverse: https://lnkd.in/eNXN5Ctf

Since the invasion of Ukraine began over one year ago, the PayPal community has donated more than $600 million to trusted nonprofits responding to the ongoing humanitarian crisis. One of those charities is World Central Kitchen, which has been on the ground in Ukraine since the conflict began and has provided 200 million meals to refugees. Thanks to the generosity of people around the world, organizations like World Central Kitchen have received mission-critical funds to support those in need.   The generosity of the PayPal community is immense, and we are inspired by the response from our community during this time of crisis.  As the conflict continues, there are still ways that you can continue to help and support relief efforts: https://bit.ly/3ybsayu Photo provided by World Central Kitchen.

Two Amazon Air cargo planes landed in Istanbul this weekend with 100,000 pounds of relief supplies including tents, sleeping bags, blankets, and heaters. Thanks to our teams and partner organizations for this joint effort to help earthquake survivors in Türkiye and Syria.

Sustainability, diversity, and inclusivity are essential to Wipro, and we are committed to developing an inclusive supply chain that mirrors the communities and consumers it serves.So we launched the Wipro Inclusion & Diversity Opportunity for Vendors (WINDOV) to provide direct communication between entrepreneurs from historically underrepresented groups or areas and Wipro’s CPO team.Interested vendors can register to participate in a WINDOV Virtual Conclave, where they will present to Wipro’s Supplier Diversity team and real buyers. Vendors that demonstrate scalability and compatibility with Wipro’s buying needs can receive immediate recommendation for empanelment, documented that same day. Throughout it all, Wipro’s Supplier Diversity Team offers stewardship to suppliers as needed, for a smoother, shorter onboarding process.To learn more about WINDOV, or to register for a Virtual Conclave, visit the WINDOV homepage: https://bit.ly/3XRLexz#OneWipro #ESG #Sustainability #Diversity #Inclusion #SupplyChain Ekinath Khedekar

I don’t have a recent curly hair corporate photo…..it’s just happened that on the day of the latest shoot I had straight hair but I do now have a photo subscription with a local photographer so this will soon change!!My first batch of corporate photos when I started the business were curly and I still use them I am mixed race, I grew up in a single parent home, my mum absolutely adored our curls but we didn’t have any one around us to show us protective styles or the best products for our hair.My dad has dreads 😍I had really sensitive skin so any products back then for my curls would make me break out in itchy rashes so I would gel, slick and straighten my hair.Anybody remember the days of straightening the hair with an iron (actual clothes iron) Interviews and when I worked in corporate I would slick back a bun or straighten my hair but I am lucky I have not been directly discriminated for my hair.Comments yesI would never dare braid my hair for work back then because nobody else did I would feel quite uncomfortable when a big deal was made of my hair when I used to wear it down to work. Even worse when people tried to paw me or ask to touch my hair !! The reality now for me is I have started a journey finally embracing my bajan curls a curly head of hair that changes each day depending on the weather, the evening protective style, the finger detangle and my own mood!!For the first time thanks to my son educating me and the help of social media I embrace my curls I couldn’t pic a favourite curly picture so sharing a few Thank you LinkedIn and Dove I LOVE my curls and I will never pat them flat again #blackhairisprofessional

I would like to wish all the amazing women out there, a Happy International Women’s Day! Today, is an opportunity to celebrate the incredible women around us - our mothers, wives, sisters, daughters, friends, and colleagues at work, who each day go above and beyond to navigate challenges and make a difference to the world around them. As a woman in tech, it fills me with such pride to see the innumerable women who are pushing the boundaries on engineering excellence, innovation, and leadership to shape the industry. While we have come a long way in bridging the gender equity gap in the tech sector, there is still so much more to be done.   I want to take a moment to express my gratitude to my family, managers, mentors, sponsors, fellow colleagues for their allyship and to the inclusive environment at Microsoft that helped me make my own choices and bring my authentic self to work. At Microsoft, we have embraced innovation that puts people at the center and to ensure that inherent biases do not creep into our products. Each of us has an opportunity to be aware of our systemic privileges and ask ourselves who is around the table, and more importantly who is not.  Sharing my favorite quote from Katy Perry that says, “I’m every woman. It takes a village to make me who I am.”  As we celebrate Women’s history month, we want to bring to you, inspirational stories of Lead, Inspire, Grow, Help, and Thrive #betheLIGHT campaign each week. Sharing our first story on: Lead at Microsoft #Lead #BetheLIGHT #WomeninTech #WomenHistoryMonth #IWD2023 #MicrosoftCloudIDC #MicrosoftLife Arun Kishan Erin Chapple (Bourke-Dunphy) Girish Bablani Rajiv Kumar Anant Maheshwari Ashish Babbar Ashish Shah Asim Mitra Aparna Kondaboina Daryl Pinto M S Ganesh Hari Narayan Meher Afroz Sundeep Kunchala Vijay Mamtani Vijay Rajagopalan Vishwa Kumbalimutt Aloka Mitra Deepak Menon Deepak Pratinidhi Rajkumar Mohanram Roshni Chattopadhyay Sundar Srinivasan Anand Gupta Aneesh Mehta Oindrila Chauhan Ira Gupta Dr. Rohini Srivathsa Meenakshi Arun Subramanian Jyothirmayi Anugu Prema Patri Debu Barve Shweta Gupta Srividya Kotra Manu Aery Sireesha Vemparala Neha Gupta Anu Raghavan Ankita Sanghvi Vandana Shah Moumita (Moon) Basu

Our ‘Breast Cancer Screening Device’ won 2 prizes at the Hollomon Health Innovation Challenge !!I’m glad to let you know that my team "Fight for 98" consisting of Thakur Alabhya Singh- Masters in Technology Innovation student, Nancy- Senior studying Molecular Biology, and Rishabh G. - Masters in Electrical Engineering student and I won the 'IntuitiveX Best Idea for Medical Device Award' of $2500 and 'Connie Bourassa-Shaw Spark Award' of $1000 for a breast cancer self-screening device at the Hollomon Health Innovation Challenge organized by Buerk Center for Entrepreneurship and University of Washington - Michael G. Foster School of Business last Thursday (03/03/2023) . We previously received $2000 prototype funding from the Buerk Center for Entrepreneurship as well. The Hollomon Health Innovation Challenge is an exciting extracurricular competition that gives students the opportunity to come up with meaningful solutions to big problems the world faces today related to health. The competition is open to undergrads and grad students at accredited colleges and universities across the Cascadia Corridor – Washington, Oregon, Idaho, and British Columbia, as well as Alaska.The prototype uses a custom-built 3x3 sensor mat coupled with an accelerometer connected to an Adafruit ESP32 feather that maps the readings of the sensor matrix to a TFT screen and uploads the data to the cloud. This data can be sent to an app that prompts the user to move the device across the breast and map the cancerous lumps, while an ML model takes care of the localization and the noise in the data.I specially thank – Sreejith S for the help during the event ,Yana Sosnovskaya for sharing her PhD work with ultrasound technologies and Carly Taylor& Kyle Boerstler, PhD for helping me pull off this project by allowing flexibility for my internship work at Activision. I also thank University of Washington College of Engineering and University of Washington, Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering for their support. I am glad that I got to work on such a ubiquitous issue that affects so many people's lives. I see potential for impact in this area and would continue to work on this. #breastcancer #machinelearning #hic #opentowork

Just wanted to put out my thoughts regarding relocation. I have been observing a trend of many companies offering remote roles while some companies are still asking employees to relocate. While there are pros and cons to both approaches, I just wanted to outline some of the struggles for a complete relocation from an employee point of view-1. Finding movers-  If the company provides relocation assistance great! , else you will need to get different quotes and start packing your stuff.  You will need to schedule movers and plan your travel accordingly.2. Finding a new place to live - Again, even with relo assistance it's hard to quickly find a new apartment or home which matches your criteria of no of bedrooms, parking spaces, yard etc  and it's more challenging if you are moving to a more expensive place. This is especially challenging if employer does not offer temporary housing. Plus additional hassle of selling or renting your current home as applicable. 3. Car shipping- Apart from the move you will need to find a good company to ship your cars. Some people employ a strategy to sell cars and buy new ones to prevent this.4. Social - You can always find new coworkers but it's hard to start making social connections from scratch. This becomes increasingly difficult as you get older. Social life may include work friends, yoga friends,  friends you take a walk with, friends you have coffee with, neighbours etc. Having this community around is extremely crucial for your mental health and overall well being. Building this back takes a lot of time. 5. Healthcare- Sometimes it may take months to find a good primary care physician in your insurance network, this also includes letting go of your favourite doctor or dentist and go through a gruelling find in another city or location. This is especially hard for people with health issues. 6. Kids or pets- Finding a good daycare or boarding for your pet, finding playdates for your kids, schooling change for kids, friends also would change for kids. This is a huge social challenge for the little ones. 7. Weather- When moving to a colder or hotter place, it takes time to acclimate to the weather.8.Misc- From redirecting mail to getting a new driver's license for the state, there are some additional misc items which need to be taken care of when moving. 9. Finding another/remote job for your spouse/ family member. From my perspective, this is a very long gruelling process and takes months if not years for someone to shift base completely. Is it really worth asking someone move and change their entire life? Wouldn't it be beneficial to the company if the employee instead works from their home and is productive immediately?What do you think? Should employers move to-1. Completely remote or 2. Keep it on site for jobs completely doable on a laptop. Do let me know in the comments! Also feel free to add if I've missed any points above. Thank you! 🙂

A few weeks ago, I came across a movement created by Dove and LinkedIn support of the CROWN Act to reinforce that #BlackHairIsProfessional. For many years, I too felt that wearing my hair straight was more professional and often hid my curls when it came to those really important meetings. Dove co-founded the CROWN Coalition to advance the CROWN Act in an effort to help end hair discrimination in the workplace. I love this movement and how it is shedding light and educating workplaces on topics hardly ever spoken of when I grew up.  #PassTheCROWN #BlackHairIsProfessional.

Today, we announced a breakthrough in quantum computing. In simple terms, we’ve achieved another step in our effort to build a large scale quantum computer. In more technical terms, our Quantum AI researchers have experimentally demonstrated that it’s possible to reduce errors by increasing the number of qubits. Someday, we believe quantum computers will be used to find solutions to some of the world’s most complex problems — from identifying molecules for new medicines to designing more efficient sustainable technologies. In the meantime, we’ll continue to responsibly research and develop this emerging technology. Learn more about the details of this breakthrough → https://goo.gle/3lXaljV

5 months to go for internships and placements, 5 ways to make the most of Leetcode:1. Study plans: Definitely the most underrated feature on Leetcode. Look for the DP, Interview, and DS study plans on Leetcode’s problemset page to get better at various important concepts everyday!2. Daily Challenge: Simple. Make a pact to solve the Daily challenge till you get your desired offer. This will help you revise and stay consistent. 3. Weekly and Biweekly contests: Again, same pact, never miss a contest until you get an offer. Upsolve and target the first 3 questions with high speed and accuracy.4. Discuss section: Make this your best friend. Read the top voted posts, understand different approaches, and even post your own solutions!5. Featured lists: The “Top 100 liked” and “Top Interview” questions lists can be your bestfriends if you want the best results within limited time!Bonus: The SQL questions on Leetcode are a one of the best practice sets out there!#interviewpreparation #placements #softwaredevelopment #interviewtips #internships

Sharing step-by-step plan & resources I followed to master my programming during college & crack Infosys SES, Morgan Stanley, Adobe interviews.  🔥 𝐒𝐚𝐯𝐞 & 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐧𝐨𝐰 :) The golden key I followed was to keep a step-by-step plan in place to navigate, built my skills according, and stayed consistent. Here's my strategy:🚀 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 𝟏: 𝐂𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐬𝐞 𝐚 𝐋𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐮𝐚𝐠𝐞There are many programming languages out there, so it can be challenging to know which one to start with. The best approach is to choose a language that aligns with your interests and goals. For example, if you want to develop websites, learning HTML, CSS, and JavaScript is a great place to start. If you're interested in machine learning, you may want to start with Python.🚀𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 𝟐: 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐁𝐚𝐬𝐢𝐜𝐬Once you've chosen a language, it's time to learn the basics. You can find countless resources online, including tutorials, videos, and online courses. Here are five websites that offer free resources to help you learn the basics:- Codecademy- FreeCodeCamp- Udemy- Khan Academy- W3SchoolsThese websites offer a wide range of courses covering everything from programming fundamentals to more advanced topics.🚀 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 𝟑: 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐬The best way to solidify your understanding of programming is to build projects. This not only helps you apply what you've learned but also gives you a chance to put your skills to the test. You can find project ideas online or come up with your own. Here are five websites that offer free project ideas:- GitHub- Project Euler- HackerRank- CodeWars- CodinGameThese websites offer a wide range of project ideas, from simple to complex, that you can use to practice your programming skills.🚀 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 𝟒: 𝐍𝐞𝐭𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐂𝐨𝐥𝐥𝐚𝐛𝐨𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞Networking and collaborating with other programmers can help you learn new skills, get feedback on your projects, and stay motivated. Here are five websites where you can network with other programmers:- Stack Overflow- GitHub- Reddit- Discord- HackerRankThese websites offer a platform where you can connect with other programmers, ask questions, and share ideas.🚀 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 𝟓: 𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐲 𝐔𝐩 𝐭𝐨 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐞Finally, programming is an ever-evolving field, so it's essential to stay up to date with the latest developments. You can do this by reading blogs, following industry experts on social media, attending webinars, and attending conferences. Here are five websites where you can stay up to date with the latest programming trends:- Hacker News- Reddit/r/programming- Medium- Dev.to- InfoQBy following this strategy and utilizing the free resources offered by the five websites mentioned above, you'll be on your way to mastering programming.Follow Priya Vajpeyi for more!LinkedIn LinkedIn for Creators LinkedIn News India #technology #innovation #marketing #creativity #jobseekers #careers

Google, Microsoft and Amazon laid off more than 70,000 employees last year. More layoffs are underway. Their profits in last quarter (not year, one quarter!) 2022: - Google: 40Bn$- Microsoft: 35Bn$- Amazon: 19.65Bn$ Important lessons if you are aiming for tier-1 jobs: [1] You are either a cost centre or profit centre to your firm. If you bring in 10L a year and get a salary of 8L, you will survive (if you are lucky), else you will not. [2] A good firm is a launchpad to better things. Not, the destination in itself. Don't get too cozy once you make it to the top firm. [3] A firm's cardinal goal is to look after its shareholders. And, your cardinal goal is to look after your career, very similar to how your CEO does. Brutal as it may sound: Team building exercises, dinners/lunches, over-arching visions of how the firm is changing the world are all theatrics that keeps you motivated to contribute to your firm. Nothing more. Don't lose sight of the fact that you are a one person army, who needs to look after your career.
I’m 47. Harry Styles is 29. If we judged musicians like we judge candidates, he’d be out of work and I'd be selling out stadiums.It's time to rethink how we equate years of experience with skill.

One of the best pieces of career advice I got in my early career is to “Talk to people”. I used to talk to people at very transactional levels especially when I had a job/an ask in my mind. This made me miss a larger opportunity to know about the problem that person is solving/working on. After getting that advice, I started asking out to people for a coffee chat, without any task in mind. It was super uncomfortable for me to start this. I had doubts/questions like what topic should I discuss, how to build the conversation, am I wasting his/her time, etc. Over a period, I started enjoying these conversations. It eventually became my habit. Lots of my learnings and exposure came from these casual chats. I got opportunities to work with a few great teams I never thought about. I identified use cases that I never believed existed. A few discussions stretched from 20 minutes to 1 hour and eventually became a lifelong connection.I felt like those discussions gave me more learning than reading a book. One simple thing that took me so long to understand. Now, I prefer taking an average course with great people to another way around. Talking to good people opens up far more opportunities than you believe. It’s a simple process: Discuss, experiment, reflect and repeat. Just keep exploring.#ExperienceFromTheField

So Hera Pheri 3 is finally happening! Look forward to being back on set with Pareshji & Akki. Like all good things, this one took some time, but it’s a relief to finally have an answer to this question! #Films are such a huge part of our culture, and yet, not many understand what goes into making a film. Apart from creative challenges, the #businessmodel & needs of the #movie business make it as challenging as any other.There are several factors for any business to succeed - a good idea, thorough market research, a solid business plan, a skilled team, funding at the right time & a strong distribution network.The movie business isn’t very different. To explain the entirety of the movie business here would be over simplifying it. But let's just say having a good script, a set of actors & a director is literally just the start point.There’s the #financing of a movie. It's usually #studios or #productionhouses, which invest their own #capital. Their teams assess the viability of a project before deciding on the budget.Some large films are financed through pre-sales and distribution deals, in which the distribution rights for the film are sold in advance to distributors and/or streaming platforms.Like the startup world, access to financing depends on the size of the film, as well as the connections & resources available to the producers & investors involved.Another key aspect in the movie business is #distribution. It’s a complex process that involves several layers like producers, distributors & exhibitors.Once a film’s made, a studio typically either sells the distribution rights to a distributor or appoints one on a commission basis, who is then responsible for securing screens from theatre owners, negotiating terms & releasing the film in theatres. Sometimes distributors negotiate a % of the box office collections.There are several other ways to monetise films.#BoxOffice collections, domestic & international, are the primary ones. Success depends on various factors, including the star cast, genre, music & the buzz created.Then come the #TV (satellite) & #OTT (digital) rights, which are a significant % of overall revenue. These deals can be fairly structured at times. Recently these values shot through the roof, but have become more rational off late.#MusicRights are another important source of revenue. Usually sold to a #musiclabel who in turn monetise it through channels like streaming, licensing, digital ad revenues etc.Many films also tie-up with #brands for in-film placements or co-marketing activities, as an additional layer of revenue, or sometimes to offset part of the pre release marketing expenses.There are so many other aspects that make the movie business challenging - audience preferences, data & insights, IP rights & licences, pre & post production, line production, permissions, promotions, pricing etc etc33 years & 125 films later I don’t have it all figured out, but I will keep getting better at it 🙏

And if things don't work out at first, confidence helps us try again.#FREE Online Courses in 2023➡️Crash Course on Python🔗https://lnkd.in/ghg2kzBR➡️Data Science Foundation🔗https://lnkd.in/gZmitDdqPython Basics for Data Analysis🔗https://lnkd.in/dzmT7z2k➡️Data Visualization with Advanced Excel🔗https://lnkd.in/drYHVEv7➡️Excel Basics for Data Analysis🔗https://lnkd.in/dUCebmcc➡️Google Project Management🔗https://lnkd.in/dRErH-aY➡️Foundations of Project Management🔗https://lnkd.in/dbmVjdKj➡️Check this link to know how to get any course for freehttps://lnkd.in/dttZe6DzLearning how to be confident is important in every part of your life, but there are some instances where it’s crucial – especially at times where you feel like giving up.Knowing how to be confident in yourself is important beyond the workplace, too. Learning how to be more confident can help you attract a partner you can build a healthy relationship with. It can also help you effectively handle conflict and seek out new opportunities ­that will foster your personal growth.If you want to learn how to build confidence, you must be willing to change your state. Your state is essentially your mood at any given time of day. Your mood is influenced by how you feel about yourself at that point in time. The good news is you can change your state at any time – no matter what’s going on around you – as long as you know how to do it.You must change your perspective and your mindset, and choose to be confident. And part of achieving this is believing – building certainty – that you are confident. Learn how to recognize your need for control and take steps toward letting go. How much money can you make from brand collabs on Linkedin?Let's start from the beginning...99% of you are writing on LinkedIn for the wrong reasons.You're writing because:• FOMO• Looks cool• Brand collabsInstead of writing to:✅Build your business✅Build a network of HNIs✅Build a distributionWriting content and everything is all fancy, but let's do some math:→ It takes 30-40 minutes to write 1 post→ To grow actively, you have to post 25-30 times a month→ Let’s take the lower end→ So, total time invested = 30*25 minutes = 750 minutes or 12.5 hours per month!Now, you’ll also have to spend some time engaging with your audience and building a network.→ On the minimum, you’d have to spend 1 hour every day on the platform. → So, on a monthly basis, you have to spend 1*30 = 30 hours per month⇒ Total until now, 12.5 + 30 = 42.5 Hours or 5.3 working days (assuming an 8 hours work day)⏰So, you’re technically spending 1 working week in a month, just because you want to get some likes?Now, let’s make things a little bit more real.🔥 → Most people (read: students) are creating content because they want create a passive income stream via brand collabsCool. Sounds fancy. Let me break it down.→ Most brands will approach you once you cross 10,000 followers atleast → The desired commercial rate is (“number of followers”/2). → So, you’ll get around 3K-5K for one promotion. On an average students take around 6-10 months to build that kind of an audience. → So, time invested, 5.3 days/month * 6 = 31.8 Days→ You’re basically spending around a month’s time to even reach a level where you can get brand collabs.Well, if you spend this much time, day & night, learning a skill, it’ll give you returns way MORE than brand collabs and for way LONGER than just 1 post. 💸The point?Well, if you're posting on LinkedIn 'only' because you want to make money from brand collabs, you’re straight-up wasting your time. I couldn’t be more clear. Sorry.(You'll earn 10x from brand collabs on other platforms like Instagram & YT, trust me!)So, either rethink your business here, or save your time and learn something useful!Remember, spending the same time with the right strategy can give you 6-figures on LinkedIn, while you’re just stuck eyeing brand collabs!In fact, people who're making the most money out of brand collabs, their primary source of earning is not even collabs!Shall I let you in on a little secret?🤫I have 75,000+ followers and my income from brand collabs is at max 20% of my total income. Going by this percentage, you’re stuck making INR 200x from promotions when you can be making INR 800x.  Don't fool yourself. THINK PEOPLE THINK!Just because ChatGPT has made it easier to write content, it doesn't mean you'll do it without a strategy in place. Just saying :)#business #work #network #students #strategy #brand #content #money #building #writing #linkedin #learning #college #brandpromotion #brandcollaboration

My M.Tech research interview experience at Indian Institute of Science (IISc)Last year, I had the opportunity to attend the interview process of the M.Tech by Research programs at the CSA department at IISc.Firstly, for CSA, there are three pools to choose from -A. Theoretical Computer Science, consisting of Algorithms, TOC, graph theory and discrete math, cryptography and security, Approximation and randomization, geometry etc.,B. Computer Systems, consisting of operating system, architecture, compilers, computer security, high performance computing etc.,C. Intelligence Systems, consisting of machine learning, artificial intelligence and robotics, reinforcement learning etc.I chose Pool C so, I was asked questions related to areas, ranging from basic data structures and programming skills to linear algebra and probability.Prepare from standard textbooks for whatever pool you are applying. Find related NPTEL videos on YouTube and try to understand the concepts well.For example, if you are appearing for pool C then, for Linear algebra you can refer to 3blue1brown or MIT Gilbert Strang lectures on Youtube. For Probability you can refer to Sheldon Ross textbook, etc.Some of the questions I remember were 1) given some constraints can you derive uniform distribution and find it's expectation? 2) Given system of equations with some constraints what kind of solutions they have?One of the most important things that they look for is a strong understanding of fundamental concepts. They are interested in your ability to apply your knowledge to real-life problems. Mathematics is a crucial part of these programs, so they expect a strong foundation in that. They want to see how well you can approach problems and arrive at solution.This is not about how many formulas you know or how many properties you can recite. They look for your thought process and approach to the problem. Even if you cannot solve a problem, they are interested in how you discuss and approach the problem with them. They might even provide you with hints and support your thought process.During the interview, I found that the faculties were flexible about the area in which I wanted to work. You can also discuss their research work and your interest.Here are some final tips to prepare for the interview process:1. Focus on your fundamentals and make sure you understand the underlying concepts clearly.2. Don't throw fancy keywords or concepts at the interview if you don't really understand them. For example "deep learning and neural networks" etc. unless you know them well with underlying math and how they work. They can easily tell if you are not being honest.3. You can visit google scholar profile of 2-3 professors under whom you want to work and know about their ongoing research. This can be strong and positive topic of discussion during interview.Good luck to all of you!#machinelearning #gate2023 #gatecse #iiscbangalore #mtech #research

Dear Law Students, Here are some of the career paths you can pursue in IPR in India. We have compiled some of the most rewarding job opportunities in the field of IPR with the list of Law Firms you may look forward to.1. Patent Attorney: Patent attorneys specialize in drafting and prosecuting patent applications. They help clients protect their inventions and intellectual property rights.2. Trademark Attorney: Trademark attorneys specialize in registering and protecting trademarks. They advise clients on trademark law and help them secure trademark rights.3. IP Litigator: IP litigators specialize in litigating IP disputes. They represent clients in court and arbitration proceedings related to patents, trademarks, copyrights, and trade secrets.4. IP Analyst: IP analysts research and analyze patent and trademark data to provide strategic advice to clients on intellectual property matters.5. Technology Transfer Professional: Technology transfer professionals help universities and research institutions commercialize their intellectual property. They negotiate and manage licensing agreements and collaborations with industry partners.6. IP Manager: IP managers manage and protect a company's intellectual property portfolio. They develop IP strategies, conduct IP audits, and oversee IP enforcement efforts.You may look forward to join as above-mentioned roles in following organisations.1. Law Firms: Many law firms specialize in IPR and offer job opportunities for patent attorneys, trademark attorneys, and IP litigators.2. Corporations: Large corporations have in-house legal departments that manage their intellectual property portfolios. Job opportunities may be available for IP managers, IP analysts, and technology transfer professionals.3. Universities and Research Institutions: Universities and research institutions often have technology transfer offices that manage the commercialization of intellectual property generated from research.4. Government Agencies: Government agencies such as the Controller General of Patents, Designs, and Trademarks, and the Intellectual Property Appellate Board employ patent examiners, trademark examiners, and IP litigation attorneys.5. Start-ups:6. Non-Profit Organizations:Here is a list of Indian firms that specialize in IPR and may have job opportunities available:Anand and AnandRemfry & SagarKhaitan & CoLakshmikumaran & SridharanSingh & Singh Law Firm LLPSujata Chaudhri IP AttorneysK&S PartnersLexOrbisSaikrishna & AssociatesDePenning & DePenningThe list is not exhaustive. You may add the firm you may know in the comment box, as I’m unable to help more due to word limit. Kindly visit their respective website for more reference.May I suggest to save this post for your future reference. #corporations #technology  #law #arbitration #litigation #intellectualproperty #lawfirm #lawfirms #career #future #india #research #help #students #jobopportunities #universities

The call for a 6 month moratorium on making AI progress beyond GPT-4 is a terrible idea.I'm seeing many new applications in education, healthcare, food, ... that'll help many people. Improving GPT-4 will help. Lets balance the huge value AI is creating vs. realistic risks.There is no realistic way to implement a moratorium and stop all teams from scaling up LLMs, unless governments step in. Having governments pause emerging technologies they don’t understand is anti-competitive, sets a terrible precedent, and is awful innovation policy. Responsible AI is important, and AI has risks. The popular press narrative that AI companies are running amok shipping unsafe code is not true. The vast majority (sadly, not all) of AI teams take responsible AI and safety seriously. Let's invest more in safety while we advance the technology, rather than stifle progress.A 6 month moratorium is not a practical proposal. To advance AI safety, regulations around transparency and auditing would be more practical and make a bigger difference.

Computer sind dumm. Habe ich jetzt den ersten intelligenten Computer kennengelernt?Diese Frage kam mir auf dem 1. IBM Who is Who Influencer Forum. Ich dürfte mit ca. 50 anderen Forumsbesuchern im IBM Headquarter D.A.CH. den einzigen deutschen Quantencomputer besuchen.Die simple Antwort auf die Frage, ob dieser Computer intelligent ist lautet: Wir denken noch zu linear. 🤯 Schon nach 2 Minuten merkte ich, wie groß meine Wissenslücke ist. Der super spannende Vortrag von Dr. Jan-Rainer Lahmann offenbarte mir das eindringlich. Folgende 3 Insights habe ich erstmal mitgenommen.✅ Der Quantencomputer ist nicht einfach ein besserer und schnellerer Rechner. Er/Sie/Es ist eine ganz neue Art der Informationsverarbeitung und Bereitstellung. Ich muss mich dringend mit den Grundlagen der Quantenphysik vertraut machen. Sonst verstehe ich das Potenzial eines Quantencomputers nicht. ✅ Im Gegensatz zum normalen Computer kennt er mehr als 2 Zustände. Diese liegen zwischen 0-1. Das ermöglicht parallele Berechnungen. Schrödingers Katze kann also wirklich gleichzeitig leben oder nicht leben. Und damit komme ich zum spannendste Faktor. ✅ Der Quantencomputer ist NICHT für rein logische Berechnungen da. Auf die Frage, ob Schrödinger's Katze lebt, kann er nach jeder Berechnung eine andere Antwort geben. Die immer ein etwas anderes Ergebnis bedeutet.🤷‍♂️ Ganz ehrlich. Ich hab es immer noch nicht verstanden. Aber ich weiß jetzt. Ich will es verstehen.Dank des Forum's habe ich nun direkten Zugang zu den Experten. Auch im Bereich #ai war Kenza Ait Si Abbou direkt zur Beantwortung meiner Fragen vor Ort. PS: Für alle die schon weiter sind als ich. Ihr könnt das Ding kostenlos über die IBM Cloud testen.https://lnkd.in/e_UuUrXg#ibmquantum #influencer #corporateinfluencer #ibm Und mein ganz persönlicher Dank gilt den Organisatoren:innen Petra Bernhardt, Jürgen Schmitt, Katrin-Cécile Ziegler und Daniel Unkelhäußer. Es hat mir und allen Beteiligten an nichts gefehlt. Das habt ihr grandios gerockt 🤟.

At Flipkart, we truly believe that great ideas can come from anywhere, especially in a culture of innovation & entrepreneurship. The 12th edition of Flipkart’s flagship hacking event, Hackday, witnessed ~380 registrations, with teams hacking away for 24 hours, fuelled by pizzas, caffeine, and the maximiser spirit, to come up with 80 demos, of which 9 amazing hacks were shortlisted & presented to a grand jury panel of 6 Leaders across Flipkart and Microsoft. Heartiest congratulations to all the winning teams and respective members (you deserve it 👏):1st 🥇- Team StoreSense (Surbhi Mathur & Harshit Jain)2nd 🥈- Team Secure SCM (Aastha Jain, Adharsh C S, Sai Deepthi, Nikhil Vartak) 3rd 🥉- Team Prompt Love (Anantharam Vanchi Prakash, Prasad Pai, Mani Shankar Balasubramanian)Special Mention🙌 - Team AKAR (Rohan Taneja, Ayush Dalia, Koushik Rout, Ayush Jain)Kudos to all the participants for a valiant effort, as we’re confident that these solutions will surely play a vital role in empowering every Indian’s dreams by delivering value through innovation in technology & commerce. Utkarsh B (Chief Architect, Flipkart) opined that, “At Flipkart, there cannot be any story without thinking of our end customers. Ideas had novelty around eliminating cognitive overload while shopping, making it seamless, meaningful, and immersive. We could see how paradigm shifts like LLMs (Large Language Models) and vector databases can help unlock the next impactful shift in interfaces for the users.” Read more of Utkarsh’s personal thoughts on the Hackday experience here: https://lnkd.in/ge7SdvuG#WeAreMaximisers #FlipkartHackathon #IdeasMaximised #InnovationMaximisedJeyandran Venugopal | Utkarsh B | Anand Lakshminarayanan | Ambika Nichani | Poojitha Jawahar | Subin Varghese | Sagrika Padha | Albuquerque | Ravi Krishnan | Regunath B

To legal enthusiasts out there,Here is the compilation of 10 Most Important Judgments in IPR a law student must know. 1. Diamond v. Chakrabarty (1980) - This case established that genetically modified organisms are patentable subject matter under U.S. law.2. Sony Corp. of America v. Universal City Studios, Inc. (1984) - This case established the "Betamax defense," which allows for the sale of devices with substantial non-infringing uses even if they can be used for infringing purposes.3. Diamond v. Diehr (1981) - This case established that computer software can be patentable subject matter under U.S. law if it provides a tangible and useful result.4. eBay Inc. v. MercExchange, L.L.C. (2006) - This case established that an injunction is not always the appropriate remedy for patent infringement and that a court must consider the equitable factors of the case before granting an injunction.5. KSR International Co. v. Teleflex Inc. (2007) - This case established that the obviousness of an invention must be considered in light of the prior art as a whole and that a combination of known elements may be considered obvious if it yields predictable results.6. Alice Corp. v. CLS Bank International (2014) - This case established that abstract ideas implemented on a computer are not patentable subject matter under U.S. law.7. Novartis AG v. Union of India (2013) - This case involved a challenge to the patentability of a cancer drug and established that Section 3(d) of the Indian Patents Act does not allow for the patenting of new forms of known substances unless they exhibit significantly improved efficacy.8. Golan v. Holder (2012) - This case involved a challenge to the constitutionality of the Uruguay Round Agreements Act, which restored copyright protection to works that had previously been in the public domain, and established that Congress has the power to restore copyright protection to works that have fallen into the public domain.9. Festo Corp. v. Shoketsu Kinzoku Kogyo Kabushiki Co. (2002) - This case established the doctrine of equivalents, which allows a patentee to claim infringement of a patent even if the accused product or process does not literally infringe the patent claims but is equivalent to them.10. Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co. (2012) - This case involved a patent dispute between Apple and Samsung over smartphone technology and established that design patents can cover the ornamental aspects of a product, even if they are not essential to the product's function.I know, I’ve left behind many important judgements. If you know one, mention it in comment box. Drop me a message if you want to join us with many other students in discussion over IPR. #law #technology #design #india #students #novartis #legal #IPR #trademarks #patentlaw #copyright #tradesecrets #industrialdesign

In 2013, Buffer was struggling to grow its user base for its social media scheduling app. The company's co-founder, Leo Widrich, decided to reach out to users to get their feedback on the app.This is a stimulus.Every small feature you have developed goes for testing. Once the internal testing is done, there is external testing gets done by existing users or colleagues from a different field, etc.This happens whenever you push the code to production. Why?Taking a step back and deciding to talk to “non-tech” people, you understand the essential parts of the work you did, and how others are perceiving the work you do. You understand the real-world application of the technology that you have developed. As an engineer, your task is most often building the blocks. But when you take off your engineering hat, you see how people from other fields take the blocks that you have developed and make a use case that was never on your mind. So, Buffer’s founder started by asking a group of bloggers for their opinions on the app. One blogger told him that while she liked the idea of the app, she found it difficult to use and not intuitive. This feedback was surprising to him, as he had thought the app was user-friendly. You can just never know how changing the color of one button can make all the difference. Remember just because JSON is a cakewalk for you doesn’t mean it is for non-techies!When the “like” button came live, Facebook went through a phase when they were having a problem with the retention of the user. They couldn’t understand why they were failing even though they had a “like” button to make it engaging. After talking to some users, they understood that users didn’t want to “like” sad news, and this gave them so much insight. Hence, multiple reactions came into the picture. That’s why it becomes essential to talk to non-tech people to understand if what you think aligns with non-tech savvy. TL;DR -It provides perception It shows the knowledge gap.It is a way to make your technology more effective.It shows an enthusiasm in others to learn from you. This is an amazing boost to your confidence. Many times, you will find people listening to you like you are the absolute best in the industry. You might not be that person but since, you know your field, you are best at what you do. For a developer, it’s immensely necessary to understand what and how the world takes up space in the development world, and how you can take the space in the non-development world and learn from there!

#splendidsundayIt was the month of April.The month of annual financial closing.Managing Finance function for almost two decades, the task of closing books was not unprecedented.But this time there was another task at hand – one which neither me nor my team have ever tried before.Something which Finance function is never associated with.DANCE!!Finance always being labelled as a lackadaisical department; dancing came as a surprise to everyone when we nominated ourselves for Dance performance at the annual function.But I had the belief.As the Head of department, I had the conviction and my confidence rubbed on my team-mates.We knew our shortcomings – Stage Fright, not being swift movers and most importantly the pressure of annual closing.However, where there is will, there’s a way.We practiced hard, utilised the lunch hours, stayed back late after office hours and made sure we are preparing ourselves in the best way possible.I had to bring all my Project management skills on table.Deep inside our hearts, one thing was sure – Me and my team wanted to give our best.And then came the D-day!!We together hopped, swayed and slayed all the doubts in mind! YES, WE were ready to deliver!And WE delivered indeed... the Performance (𝘢𝘭𝘣𝘦𝘪𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘢 𝘥𝘪𝘧𝘧𝘦𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦𝘯𝘵) was immaculate!The applause at the end of performance reverberated in the Hall for a long, long time.The Team shined and so illuminated the True Leader!!Have you ever been in such situation as a Leader where you had to up your game and take any challenge heads on?If yes, will definitely love to hear your experiences and how YOU and YOUR team shined on the occasion.Don’t hesitate to share your experiences in the comments section and yes, #letsconnect  so that there is lot more we can share with each other and enlighten ourselves.Do send me a #connection request on LinkedIn and I will be delighted to connect.#HardHittingHimanshu#letsconnect #growtogether #leadership #finance #growthmindset #headoffinance #teamwork #confidence #bettertogether #annualconference #yearend #statutoryaudit #financeleadership #projectmanagement #splendidsunday

As the holy month of Ramadan commences, Muslims around the world prepare to fast from dawn to dusk.I wanted to share my experiences as a Googler for 15 years - how Google has supported me and more importantly, how companies around the world can create an inclusive environment for your Muslim team members -- Managing energy through the fasting period can be a challenge, so offering flexibility on working hours goes a long way in ensuring a smooth and effective month- Providing a space for your Muslim colleagues to perform ablution (use water to clean themselves) and offer their prayers- Reducing offsites that require high energy and activity. This can always be planned before or after the month- Organizing a team dinner during the month where everyone in the company can break-fast together- Every year, Muslims donate a certain proportion of wealth to charitable causes. Google has an employee program to match donations 1:1 as long as it is a registered charity. This is a great way to create social impact togetherHope these ideas go a long way in creating a more inclusive work environment for you. It certainly has at Google!Ramadan Mubarak for everyone celebrating! #GoogleRamadan #Google #GoogleMalaysia #Ramadan #LifeAtGoogle Google

Majority of people in India suffer from waterborne diseases due to deprivation of safe drinking water and affordable purification technologies. To address this issue, Mayur Ramrao (Aarohan Award 2018 winner) devised a technology which modifies existing water pumping systems to disinfect bore-well water. This modification of hand pump leads to a phenomenon known as hydrodynamic cavitation, which can disrupt the bacterial cells or make them nonviable, thereby making groundwater safe for consumption. It does not require electricity or chemicals to operate.Aarohan Social Innovation Awards helped Mayur take his water-purification technology to a larger audience.Infosys | #InfosysFoundation | #cleanwater | #drinkingwater | #ruraldevelopment

The most powerful quantum computer in Europe🇪🇺: potential for materials research, logistics and defenceA number of corporate influencers and thought leaders, including Yannick Fasters  and myself, had the opportunity to take a look at the highly complex system at the IBM Influencer Forum this week.The #IBMQuantum System One was ceremonially put into operation in 2021 in the presence of the then German Chancellor and Doctor of Physics Angela Merkel. Together with IBM, the Fraunhofer-Gesellschaft operates the quantum computer in Ehningen near Stuttgart. The special feature: All processed project and user data remain in Germany at all times and are subject to German data protection regulations. 👉😉 #dataprotection Today, the system is used by a large number of customers who want to explore the potential of this revolutionary technology for industrial use. Quantum physics will make things possible at the latest with the availability of a computer with a sufficient number of Qbits that would take an eternity with traditional computers or cannot even be calculated at all.The ultra-fast supercomputers, in combination with artificial intelligence, could create performance boosts for more value creation in the medium term. Dr. Jan-Rainer Lahmann mentioned medical technology, logistics and materials research as obvious examples of applications. For example, Volkswagen wants to use quantum computers on the one hand to develop new materials for car manufacturing, and on the other hand to simulate new urban traffic concepts for metropolises with millions of inhabitants.Experts also see the possibility of using quantum computers to stabilise critical security infrastructures, develop better algorithms for industrial production and better model battery and fuel cells.The computer in Ehningen contains 127 Qbits. If you were to order a quantum computer from IBM today, there would even be 433 quantum bits available in the Osprey system. Towards the end of the year, researchers expect a system with over 1000 quantum bits. That is a big leap forward in development. In 2018, these computers were still at 72 Qbits.Here are 10 quantum computing applications you should know about:👉Artificial intelligence👉Better batteries👉Cleaner fertilization👉Cybersecurity👉Drug development👉Electronic materials discovery👉Financial modelling👉Solar capture👉Traffic optimization👉Weather forecasting👉Climate changeThanks a lot to Petra Bernhardt, Daniel Unkelhäußer and the whole IBM team for this exciting journey into a technology that can shape the European ecosystem. #technology

As a CTO, leading a successful Atlassian cloud migration involves aligning your team and empowering them to embrace the change. 🚀Here are my top 3 tips to get your team on board:1️⃣ Communicate the Benefits: 🤔Emphasize the advantages of cloud migration, such as streamlined collaboration, automatic updates, and improved security. Show how these benefits directly impact your team's day-to-day work and help them achieve their goals faster and more efficiently.2️⃣ Address Concerns Proactively: 🤝Be open to addressing your team's questions and concerns. Offer concrete solutions and resources, such as training sessions or documentation, to help them overcome challenges and build confidence in their ability to adapt to the new environment.3️⃣ Foster a Culture of Collaboration: 🌐Encourage cross-functional teams to work together on the migration process. This not only promotes a sense of ownership but also accelerates learning and sharing of best practices.Keep your team engaged and excited, and you'll see a smoother, more successful cloud migration! 📈#Atlassian #CloudMigration #CTO #Leadership #TeamCollaboration

On April 3, 1973, Martin Cooper stood on a sidewalk on Sixth Avenue in Manhattan with a device the size of a brick and made the first public call from a cell phone to one of the men he’d been competing with to develop the device.“I’m calling you on a cell phone, but a real cell phone, a personal, handheld, portable cell phone,” Cooper, then an engineer at Motorola, said on the phone to Joel Engel, head of AT&T-owned Bell Labs.While cell phones would not be available to the average consumer for another decade, anyone walking by Cooper on the street that day could have seen history being made. https://cnn.it/3MhDK3s📸: Sandy Huffaker/The New York Times/Redux

𝗜𝗻𝗳𝗹𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗿? 𝗗𝗮𝘀 𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼𝗰𝗵 𝗱𝗶𝗲 𝗺𝗶𝘁 𝗱𝗲𝗺 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲-𝘂𝗽 𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗲𝗻 𝗙𝗶𝗹𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻 🙄Nein, sind sie nicht. Sind Menschen. Und großartige noch dazu 🤩 Denn hinter dieser leicht bescheidenen Job-Bezeichnung stecken Pioniere, die entschlossen voran gehen. Jede*r in seinen Themen. In dieser Welt, für diese Welt. Als Katrin-Cécile Ziegler mich vor genau 2 Monaten zum IBM Influencer Forum eingeladen hat, hab ich mich schon gefragt, was ich da soll. Ich gebs zu: Die ersten 2 Stunden hab ich mir das alles erst mal kritisch angeschaut. Bin ja nicht grade bekannt für Small Talk. 🤷🏼‍♀️Und dann kamen Jan Cremer, Steffen Sickinger, Tom Schneider und Lars H. Heimann um die Ecke, und waren total offen für meine tiefen Fragen. Von da an hüpfte das Herz 😉Was ich mitgenommen habe:🔵 Es ist ein sooo schönes Gefühl, Menschen in echt zu begegnen. Katrin-Cécile, Sarah Yvonne, Zackes: Ihr seid für mich der absolute Wahnsinn an Persönlichkeit!  🔵 Wie in jeder Bubble gibt’s auch hier Menschen, mit denen man sofort auf einer Wellenlänge ist und andere, bei denen das eher nicht passiert. Wie immer gilt: Focus goes where energy flows.🔵 Dieser Quantum Computer ist für mich immer noch eine Black Box. Aber klingt ziemlich spannend.🔵 Es kann so viel Positives entstehen, wenn wir Menschen zusammen bringen, die wirklich was bewegen wollen.Petra Bernhardt: Was ihr hier auf die Beine gestellt habt, ist Pionier-Arbeit erster Klasse. Danke, dass ich ein Teil davon sein durfte. Freu mich riesig aufs nächste Mal 🌟#IBMQuantum #InfluencerForum #TopicLeader #Transformation #Pioniere #Gemeinschaft #Movement #WegbegleiterFürWegbereiter PS: Falls ihr ein passenderes Wort für #Influencer findet, schreibts gern in die Kommentare. Ist mir nämlich nicht ganz geheuer...

🔒 Atlassian's Beacon will enhance security in your organization. 🔒🔍 Follow these steps to maximize its potential...🔓 Enable Beacon: If you haven't already, request access to the Beacon Beta and enable it in your Atlassian cloud products.🛠️ Customize your alert rules: Beacon continuously monitors your Atlassian products for suspicious user activity, but you can customize your alert rules to meet your organization's specific needs. For example, you can set up alerts for data exfiltration events, unusual user activity, and integration changes.🚨 Investigate alerts promptly: When you receive an alert from Beacon, investigate it promptly. Determine the alert's severity and take appropriate action, such as resetting user passwords, disabling integrations, or contacting your security team.🔋 Use Beacon to enhance your security posture: Beacon can help you detect security threats and enhance your security posture. Use the insights provided by Beacon to identify areas where your security can be improved and take action to mitigate potential risks.📖 Keep up with Atlassian security best practices: In addition to using Beacon, it's important to keep up with Atlassian news. Stay informed about security updates and new features, and ensure your organization follows recommended security practices.👍 By following these steps, you can utilize Beacon to its fullest.🛡️ Stay safe and secure! 🛡️#atlassianbeacon #security #cloud #AtlasBench #atlassiancommunity

I'm back from BDI's 2023 Young Leaders program in Berlin, where we came together with leaders from different industries and government sectors to discuss a fundamental question: What role can businesses and business leaders play in solving global challenges?The answers to today's social and economic challenges are not trivial. However, I look to the future with great optimism, which has been strengthened even further after spending a week with this diverse and inspiring group of leaders. We are united behind the idea that we not only have the opportunity, but also the responsibility to make a positive difference by working together across industries, and leading with purpose and values. I also firmly believe in the potential of technology to solve big social challenges, improve lives, and create a more equitable world. This is why I am proud of the work we do with our customers and partners to further strengthen Germany's potential. 🇩🇪 I look forward to staying connected with the amazing people I met during the program and continue to deepen our partnerships. My genuine thanks also to BDI - Bundesverband der Deutschen Industrie e.V. for providing the platform for this valuable exchange. As I'm still reflecting on learnings and takeaways, I would love to hear your thoughts too. How would you define the term #ImpactEconomy and how do you think businesses can leverage its principles to create a more sustainable and equitable future for everyone?#bdi #bdiyoungleaders #berlin #Germany #growth #prosperity #sustainability #innovation  #lifeatgoogle Google #business #leadership BDI Young Leaders: Maike Becker-Krüger, Julia Bock, CFA, Katharina Böttcher, Petra Bührer (Buehrer), Dr. Tim Ellringmann, Tim Enger, Dermot Fleischmann, Faten Gaber, Martin Hauser, Simone Heeg, Tibor Homolya, Patrick Jäger, Marina Jeworutzki, Christine Kantelhardt, Harald R. Kirchschlager, Johannes Kobbeloer, Simone Kopping, Sophie Matkovits, Laura Medina Escolano, Claudia Meister, Denis Merkle, Dr. Veronika Preuß, Mouna Romani, Sonja Roßner, Claudia Rudolph-Belger, Christian Schrade, Magdalena Sichler, née Rutz, Jan Szybalski, Nico Wilhelm and organizers + hosts: Sandra Calvaruso, Dr. Hajo Schumacher, Fritz Strempel

Building and scaling offline GT distribution is one of the most difficult things to achieve in the journey of building consumer brandsIn our journey of expanding our presence to 200+ cities & 15000+ stores, here are 3 unique things we did that helped us in the initial daysa) No Hard Sales Targets:Instead of having sales targets, we had targets on input metrics. For us, the most important metric was the number of counters visited every day and the quality of each visit.In the initial days, you will face rejection daily. And it is purely about perseverance. In the first couple of visits to big counters, the shop owner will not even speak with you. In the third visit, maybe he will offer you tea and understand about the product/brand. And maybe in the 4th/5th visit, he will give you the first order.And this behavior of the retailer is intentional to an extent. Sub-consciously he checks how serious the sales person is about building the brand. If the sales guy keeps visiting him continuously for weeks, there is a high chance that he will agree for the stock placementb) Leveraging Digital to build Retailer awareness:In each of our visits to the counters, we used to collect the business card of the shops. These business cards had the contact details of the retailers. We started creating custom audiences for the retailers and started running ads on all digital platforms.This made the brand and the product familiar to the retailers.In addition to normal feature/led ads, a lot of the ads were around awards/recognition that we had received. This built trust amongst retailersBrand Familiarity and Trust are the 2 things most critical to get a retailer to stock an early stage brand. This is why you would often hear legacy brands activating TV and Print ads to get trade to believe in the brand. But digital allows you to do the same in a much more cost effective and intelligent wayc) In Person Sellout:Placement for the first time is still relatively easier. But if the products don’t sell from the counters, the brand is dead and buried.To enable sellouts, I used to go and work as a shop boy in the top counters on weekends( high customer walk-ins). In addition to the obvious benefit of kickstarting sellout from the stores, this helped us in multiple ways:- When the retailer see you pitching the product, they get an understanding on what to communicate. Their training gets completed- It helps you get a lot of first hand consumer insights which are used to improve product & marketing communicationOver time, this got institutionalized and everyday our sales folks and all leaders in market visits interact and pitch to customers wherever possible.Building and scaling General Trade in India is tough. But then again, when was the last time you found something worth building which wasn't tough :)P.S. Old pic from one of the days when I was working as a shopboy :)

We've collected trending products helpful during Ramadan in the Middle East, North Africa, and Indonesia. 3️⃣ Visual shopping made easy - take a photo or screenshot of a delicious dessert or decoration that caught your eye, and use Google Lens to find exact or similar results to shop from or to explore for inspiration.4️⃣ Cooking inspiration at your fingertips - type the name of a dish and "recipe" into Search to discover a list of recipes to get inspiration and instructions on how to master each dish.And that's not all! Chief Data Scientist Juan M. Lavista Ferres and his team at Microsoft's AI for Good Lab are using AI to help organizations #ImagineMore ways to address some of the world’s greatest challenges.​​From making technology more accessible to helping track climate change, Juan works to convert human knowledge and data into code that can be read by AI and machine learning. ​Juan was born and raised in Uruguay, in South America, so English isn’t his native language. “AI models assist me in finding the appropriate terms to use,” he says.​It’s with this data that AI is empowering people to find innovative solutions for a more equitable and sustainable future.​​

Last year, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis won praise from the right for retaliating against Disney for its CEO’s decision to (rather timidly) wade into the public discourse over a contentious state law. In that first round of Florida’s GOP vs The Walt Disney Company, DeSantis landed a body blow that ultimately cost Disney CEO Bob Chapek his job.For DeSantis, a potential presidential contender in 2024, the standoff burnished his reputation on the right as a shrewd leader who won’t be easily pushed around, not even by one of the state’s largest employers.But now, in round two, DeSantis, age 44, is going up against longtime Disney boss Bob Iger, a Hollywood power player with decades more experience on the national stage. And Iger, at age 72, isn’t pulling any punches. Iger, who retired in 2020 only to return to the helm nearly three years later when Chapek was forced out (more on that later), doesn’t have much time to mess around. He’s given himself a two-year deadline to line up a successor, and he’s got to do that all while trying to reinvigorate a 100-year-old sprawling media conglomerate.Analysis by CNN's Allison Morrow

Balancing parenthood with maintaining career momentum is no easy task. Becky, a Vice President in our Asia Pacific Investment Banking Division and mother of an 8-year old son, credits a supportive work culture in helping her find the right work-life balance for her and her family.     “I’ve been able to leverage parental initiatives provided by Morgan Stanley and have always been supported by my managers and colleagues – many of whom are parents themselves so are able to empathize,” says Becky. At Morgan Stanley, we are dedicated to ensuring women are represented across all divisions and at all levels within the firm, as part of our commitment to diversity. For Becky, this included making use of the local benefits and initiatives designed for working moms, such as extended parental leave, parental transition coaching and firm-sponsored employee-led networks to support women. Find out more: https://mgstn.ly/3Zj4V0B

First-time homebuyers in America have never been older, and an influx of all-cash buyers, as well as a younger generation leaning financially on their parents for longer than ever before, has made it staggeringly difficult for older, lower-income renters to save enough for a home. In 2022, the typical American getting keys to a starter home was 36 years old, an all-time high, and many buyers are into their golden years before they can scrounge together a down payment.About 20% of buyers between the ages of 50 and 59 in 2022 were purchasing for the first time, according to Zillow’s Consumer Housing Trends Report. Eleven percent of buyers aged 60 to 69 were first-time homeowners, and among buyers over the age of 70, 7% were buying for the first time.For many of those buyers, the desire to lock in costs as they transition to a fixed income is reason enough to finally shift from renting to owning, said Jeff Tucker, a senior economist at Zillow. “As they’re considering how their pension, social security and income will be fairly fixed moving forward, the beauty of the 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage is that you don’t have to worry that rising rents could force you out,”  Zucker said.

Virgin Orbit, the rocket company founded by British billionaire Richard Branson, has filed for bankruptcy in the United States.The announcement comes just days after Virgin Orbit said it would lay off about 85% of its workforce to reduce expenses since it could not secure additional funding.“While we have taken great efforts to address our financial position and secure additional financing, we ultimately must do what is best for the business,” Dan Hart, chief executive of Virgin Orbit, said in the statement posted on its website.

I was taking an interview,suddenly the candidate dropped off the call,we were in the middle of solving a coding question.I could anticipate that the internet broke on his end,and after around 5 minutes, he joined again.He was all in panic mode. 😢"Sorry, sorry. I'm extremely sorry", he said.He started explaning,"I just lost my internet connection due to a power cut."I could hear him breathing heavily,I assume, he must have ran fast to fix the issue.Because of this disturbance of 5-10 minutes,he just lost where he was in the coding problem.He almost started thinking everything once again from scratch, because of this small unforeseen issue he just lost a lot of precious time in the interview.So what am I trying to explain is,0. Whenever you're giving an interview, just keep a backup internet option available at your end.So, keep your hotspot running on your phone. ✅1. I've seen a similar situation happening to a candidate when he had to run and get his charger from another room.So, keep your charger plugged in. ✅2. Also, keep a notebook and pen next to you, you never know. ✅LastlyPlease don't panic,If anything unforeseen happens, just keep calm.Remember that on the other side of the call is your friend.It's okay if something messes up,interviewers understand that,It can happen at their end too. 😌So,Just try to keep calm,don't over-explain,take a deep breath,focus on where you were,and continue with the interview like nothing happened. ✌️And remember,`Every interviewer was once a candidate.` 🤷‍♂️#interview #softwareengineer #career #coding

Teaching #creativity at NMIMS has been real fun! This cohort of MBA-Tech VIII sem is the third batch I am teaching creativity and ethics in  #marketing. Today attempt was made to provoke creativity among students. Students divided in group did brainstorming and came out with a 5 themes related to their institute NMIMS. To begin with they started with creating posters. Few takeaways:1) In everyone there is a hidden creativity, just it requires to be realised and provoked. #education 2) creativity should generate fresh ideas and need to be problem solving.3) It needs divergent thinking, finally coverages, it’s science and art.4) In academics, even corporate we should build a culture of idea nurturing.5) This will lead to Apply and Create Level of Education.#nmims # #students #management

Recently Completed 6 Years at Google. The Professional Journey that started in 2012 is going strong. Sharing some personal moments from this journey:✨Pic 1: 2017, Second month at Google and Trip to Mountain View Office. This one place is full of ideas and god speed execution 🫡✨Pic 2: Just graduated from College in 2012 with no idea where to go. Just a happy state of mind that I have a campus placement 🙃✨Pic 3: From 2014, When got the guru mantra from my friend on top of nandi hill to start focusing on CAT since Tech seems to be bit tricky for me 😅✨Pic 4: From 2015, At CAT percentile of 97 missed IIMA by huge margin but this was the day when me along with my friends won IIMAs prestigious case competition 😅✨Pic 5: From 2019, When I met the special one and graduated from bachelorhood. She is the one who keeps me motivated and makes life easier 😀✨Pic 6: From 2023, Just one of the few random days when you are full of gratitude because of fun loving people around you 😇One of the biggest learning’s for me in this journey has been “Issues and challenges get solved sooner or later, the way you handle the situation makes or breaks your reputation”.Listen actively, Act diligently and Respect others. 📍Pandas is a popular data manipulation library in Python, but it has some limitations when it comes to handling very large datasets:1) Memory limitations: Pandas loads the entire dataset into memory, which can be a problem if the dataset is very large and exceeds the available memory on your machine. This can cause the program to crash or become unresponsive.2) Limited scalability: Pandas is designed to work on a single machine, which limits its ability to handle large datasets that require distributed computing across a cluster of machines.3) Limited parallelism: Pandas does not support parallel processing out of the box, which means that it cannot take advantage of multiple CPU cores or threads to speed up computations.PySpark, on the other hand, is a distributed computing framework that can handle large datasets by distributing the computation across a cluster of machines. Some of the benefits of using PySpark over Pandas include:1) Scalability: PySpark can scale to handle datasets that are too large for Pandas to handle on a single machine. It can distribute the computation across a cluster of machines, which allows it to handle datasets that are terabytes or petabytes in size.2) Fault tolerance: PySpark is designed to handle failures in a distributed environment. If a machine fails or becomes unresponsive, PySpark can automatically reassign the tasks to another machine, ensuring that the computation continues without interruption.3) Parallel processing: PySpark can take advantage of multiple CPU cores or threads to speed up computations. This can significantly reduce the time required to process large datasets.Overall, PySpark is a powerful tool for distributed computing and big data processing, which makes it a good alternative to Pandas when dealing with very large datasets that exceed the memory and processing power of a single machine.#datascience #dataengineering #machinelearning #datascientist

Most people don't negotiate their salary offer,they find it uncomfortable and awkward,they think it's unprofessional,But it is not,Negotiating Salary isn't a sin,If you feel that the offer is less than you deserve,have a healthy discussion, do negotiate. ✅Initial Offer != Final Offer 🤷🏽‍♂️A 10 minutes discussion often decides what you earn for many coming years. It's important, very important. 💁🏽‍♂️A job offer is like a business deal.You help the company with your skills and expertiseand the company pays you for it. 🤝Hiring is extremely expensive for a company.The company wants you as much as you want that job, if not more.Adding a couple of lakhs is generally not a big deal for most companies.So never hesitate to negotiate, it's not a sin. 💁🏽‍♂️Read More about it from the link in the first comment. 👇and Remember,`If you're underpaid, It's YOUR fault.` 🤷🏽‍♂️Cheers,Akshay Saini

I was delighted to open Barclays’ ESG Conference in New York; ‘Navigating the realities of transition’. We welcomed 270 clients and heard from distinguished guest speakers Mark Carney, Ernest J. Moniz, Robin Hayes and other experts on carbon markets, the impact of geopolitics on transition, and energy security. We have an important role to play in helping our clients to navigate the complexities of the transition to a low carbon economy. The purpose of our ESG Conference was to bring together clients and experts to discuss the challenges and opportunities of the transition, and to explore new thinking.Thanks to Brian Reilly, Marie Freier, Daniel Hanna for your efforts in organising the event.

I’m sure many of you are aware that having a strong command of data structures and algorithms is crucial for landing a job in top product-based companies like Google, Amazon, and MicrosoftDespite knowing the reality, most of working professionals lack confidence in their DSA skills. So, if you are one of those people who aren’t confident regarding DSA or are planning to upskill, then this post might be beneficial for you.Being a working professional myself, I understand that managing time for upskilling along with your job can become extremely tricky. I’ve been working in software development since the mid-90s, and large enterprises, since the late-90s. In 2008, I started working on ways to bring Agile to enterprise IT teams and other non-software organizations. Since that time, I've seen most large companies pursue Agile, often setting goals to aggressively change the way they work. In the past few years, due to COVID, this has really accelerated, with many enterprise organizations trying to finally make Agile a reality. As that has happened, more are starting to question if that shift is worth it. In this post, I explore why this is and what the alternatives are. #softwaredevelopment #softwareengineering #agile #technology #enterprise #digital #BeCognizant #IntuitionEngineered

My interview experience for Microsoft , interviews for my prior organization and here were quite different.Here’s how the interview rounds at Microsoft went for me : Round 1 → It was an online test on the Codility platform. I got 2 coding questions to solve and it was necessary that the solution code should be optimized and plagiarism free.Good knowledge of DS & Algo is required to pass this round.Round 2 → This was the First Interview round and was based on Problem solving in DS & Algo.One can expect two problems from DSA concepts. Good knowledge of Advance DSA was required here.Round 3 ->  This interview round was of System design based and it can have low level or High Level Design problem where I have to design a system at scale.Good command over System Design is important here.Round 4  -> Managerial interview round → mostly related to prior work, projects, situation based questions, behavioral questions, and simple DSA problems.Finally, I was selected at Microsoft.I’m glad for all the support I had from my friends who helped me with mock interviews. But in case you need personal mentorship and structured learning, then I’ll suggest you checkout Bosscoder Academy.They’ve already helped 1000+ software engineers crack their dream roles by providing -✅ Structured curriculum to master problem solving in DSA, System Design and Full Stack Development.✅ Personal guidance from top software engineers working in companies such as Microsoft, Apple etc.✅ Live classes and 24x7 doubt support to keep learners consistent.So if you want a good support system to prepare for top companies, checkout - http://bit.ly/3MnE9kN #dsa #upskilling #collab #interviewexperience
